Polygon

It is used to create polygons. There are different ways to construct them. One is from the toolbar and second is from the Polygon command. We will discuss both.

Polygon Tool

  • Open the Geogebra Classic either from the online platform or the offline platform.
  • From the toolbar menu click on the polygon tool (see the picture below).

 

  • There are four type of polygons that we can construct
  • Polygon
  • Regular Polygon
  • Rigid Polygon
  • Vector Polygon

 

Polygon Command

We can draw the polygons via the Polygon() command.

  • Polygon({list of points})

Draw the polygon defined by the points in the list.

  • Polygon(point,..., point)

Draw a polygon with given points.

  • Polygon(point,point, number of vertices)

Draw a regular polygons with the given number of vertices

 

Exercise

  1. Draw a 12-gon using the Regular Polygon Tool.

  2. Draw a trapezium using Polygon Tool. You can use the Parallel Line Tool.

  3. Draw the following star

    Hints:

  • Draw a regular pentagon using Regular Polygon Tool.

    • Draw all the diagonal using the Line Segment Tool.
    • Finally use the Show Object by selecting unwanted objects.

    Can you change the size by dragging some points??

Distance and Length

As the name suggests, this tool is used to measure the distance between two points, two lines or a point and a line. It is also used to measure the length of a line-segment. This can be done in two ways; one is from the toolbar and second is from the Distance() and the Length() command. We will discuss both.

Distance and Length Tool

  • Open the Geogebra Classic either from the online platform or the offline platform.
  • From the toolbar menu click on the Distance and Length tool under the Angle tool (see the picture below).

 

 

Distance and Length command

We can use this via the Distance() and Length() command.

  • Distance(Point, Object)

    • This computes the (shortest) distance between a point and an object.
    • This is a very powerful tool to compute the distance.

  • Distance(Line, Line)

    As the name suggests, compute the distance between two lines.

  • Length(Object)

    This computes the length of the prescribed object. For example

    • Length(Point)

      This returns the length of the line segment joining origin to the point (or length of the position vector of the given point)

    • Length(Vector)

      Returns the length of the vector

    • Length(Arc)

      Returns the length of an arc

    • Length(List)

      Returns the number of elements in a list

  • Length(function, starting point, ending point)

    Computes the length of a function between the two points.

  • Length(Curve, start t-value, end t-value)

    Computes the length of the parametric curve between to .

  • Length(Curve, starting point, ending point)

    Computes the length of the curve between two points.

 

Exercise

  1. Draw a quadrilateral using the Polygon Tool and then using the Distance and Length Tool measure the length of each side. Also find its perimeter using the Length Tool
  2. Take any two points, say and and find out the distance between them using the Distance and Length Tool.
  3. Draw the function . Using the Point on the object Tool to take two points on the graph of . Use the Length(function, point, point) to find out the length of the curve between those two points.
  4. Draw a circle by using any tool. Then find its circumference.

Area

This tool is used to measure the area of a polygon and conics. This can be done in two ways; one is from the toolbar and second is from the Area().

Area Tool

  • Open the Geogebra Classic either from the online platform or the offline platform.

  • From the toolbar menu click on the Area tool under the angle symbol (see the picture below).

 

Area command

We can compute the area of any polygon or conics by the Area() command

  • Area(Polygon)

    This computes the area of the polygon

  • Distance(Conic)

    This computes the area of a conic section, that is, area of circle or ellipse.

 

Exercise

  1. Draw a circle by using Circle: Center & Radius tool . Then use the Area tool to compute its area.
  2. Draw a hexagon by using Polygon Tool and compute its area.
  3. Draw a square and rectangle of equal area. The point of this exercise is to use various tools. I am allow to drag a point of square so that its area will be changing but at the same time the area of the rectangle should also change (without changing manually).

 

Slope

This tool is used to find out the slope of a line. It can be used in two ways; from the toolbar and from the Slope() command.

Slope Tool

  • Open the Geogebra Classic either from the online platform or the offline platform.
  • From the toolbar menu click on the Slope tool under the angle symbol (see the picture below).

Slope command

We can find out the slope of a line by the Slope() command.

  • Slope(Line)

    This returns the slope of the given line.

 

Exercise

  1. Draw a line using the Line tool. Then using the Slope tool find out its slope. Finally, drag the points to see the change in the slope.
  2. By using the tools that we have used, show that slope of two parallel lines are same.
  3. By using the tools that we have used, show that the product of slope of two perpendicular lines is .

 

 

Introduction to Slider

  • Sliders in Geogebra are mostly used to vary values of variables.

  • It is used to make animation.

  • Slider can also be accessed in two ways; one is from the toolbar and second is from the Slider(). We will only discuss through the slider toolbar.

  • For accessing it, we need to find , under which the slider is there (see the image below).

  • The following watch can be made with the help of slider.

    How to use sliders

    • After selecting the slider and then clicking somewhere on the graphing window, a pop-up window comes which looks like

     

    • Three kind of sliders are there:

      • Number
      • Angle
      • Integer

    • We need to provide the interval and the increment

    • Under the slider tab we have

    • By the Fixed we can fix the slider position
    • By selecting Random the slider will vary randomly.
    • The drop-down has two options, Horizontal and Vertical they do as the name suggests.
    • Under the Animation tab, we an set the speed and type of variation, whether it is increasing, decreasing or both.

Exercise

  1. Make three sliders

    • A slider from to with an increment of and the slider should be vertical and make it only increasing.
    • A slider which takes integer value from to make it increasing once.
    • A slider which take the value from to with an increment of and make it decreasing.

  2. Using Slider tool and Regular Polygon Tool make a regular polygons having sides to .

  3.  

 

 

Text

This tool is used to write static and dynamic texts. We will explain both texts. We will only discuss this via the toolbar. At first let us see how to access. Under , we can access the text tool. See the image below.

 

Static Text

  • After clicking on the text tool and click anywhere on the graphing window.

  • A new window will pop-up, which looks something like this:

 

Dynamic Text

  • If you see the above pop-up window you can see there is something Advanced written.

  • After clicking on advanced, you can see

  • Beside the preview there is a logo of Geogebra, which is used to create the dynamic text.

  • Let us see how do we use this.

    • Suppose we draw a point A=(2,3)

    • Now after clicking on the text tool and heading to the Geogebra logo one will get something like this.

 

  • Now when one changes the point A, the text is changing.
